Replies.Reply: What do you want?
I can't take in vagrants. Here's a penny. Now take it and go.
You can move off. And if there are others with you tell them we are not alone. We have a gentleman here, and dogs.
We've had a beggar woman come, Mr Rivers. I sent her - For shame!
I thought her one of the gypsies from the cross.
There's milk and bread for you.
Shelter.
I have no strength to go.
But I must die if I am turned away.
God help me. I will die.
I - I am J -
What do you want?
I have done nothing wrong. Master Reed.
I wasn't aware it was yours.
Wicked and cruel - you are a slaver - a murderer -
I hate you John Reed. I hate you -
Bessie!
There was a light.
No - Aunt, have pity -
Please - I cannot bear it -
I shall be killed -
Have mercy, have mercy I beg you -
They go to hell.
A pit full of fire.
No sir.
I must keep in good health and not die.
You are not fit to associate with me!
You said I was a liar. Well I am not. If I was, I should say that I loved you and I don't. I dislike you the worst of anybody in the world except John Reed. He is a liar, not I.
I'll never call you Aunt again as long as I live and if anyone asks how I liked you I'll say that the very thought of you makes me sick.

I'll remember how you thrust me back into the Red Room and locked me there to my dying day. Even when you knew it was haunted and I begged to be let out. People think you are good but you are bad and hard-hearted and I'll let everyone at Lowood know what you have done!
Deceit is not my fault!
My Uncle Reed is in heaven and can see all that you do and think; so can my mother and father. They know how you hate me and wish me dead.
Don't scold me Bessie. I know you dislike me -
You don't show it.
Jane Eyre.
My name is Jane Elliott...
No one.
Yes sir.
Mr Rivers, you and you sisters have done me a great service, the greatest man can do - you have rescued me from death.
I'll tell you as much as I can. I am an orphan; brought up a dependent; educated in a charity school where I passed six years as a pupil and two as a teacher.
A good situation, where I remained until...
Do you?
You're not working at present?
I am very sorry to hear it.
I... It was a catastrophe.
I am free from any blame, sir. I was happy.
Because that is not my name.
Because I must not ever be found.
I'd appreciate it if you called me Jane. It is my own name.
I trust I will not be eating long at your expense, Mr Rivers.
I wish to work, sir. Show me how to work or how to seek work; that's all I ask.
With all my heart, sir.
Most thorough.
You're not allowed to speak to me. I must be shunned.
He said I was a liar.
I am not a liar!
How do you bear it?
Being struck.
If she hit me I would get that birch from her hand and break it under her nose.
I have always been excluded and alone and hated. Miss Abbott used to call me an ugly little toad.
What?
What do you mean?
Is that true?
Angels?
Why?
Why ever not?
Can he not do God's work here?
In one thing you are fortunate.
You have each other.
Helen.
You're cold.
Back to your father?
Then where?
No...
No...
Then he must save you.
I won't leave you.
No, no, no -
Have you something for me to do?
That's Miss Temple on her wedding day. She was my teacher; a great influence on me. Under her guidance I became a teacher too.
No, Mary, please -
Mr Rivers, I wondered if you had yet heard of any work that I could do.
I shan't mind what I do.
Mr Rivers, I thank you heartily and I accept with all my heart.
I will save them until they are wanted. They will keep.
Yes. Excuse me.
Are you Mrs Fairfax?
Am I to have the pleasure of meeting Miss Fairfax tonight?
Miss Fairfax - my pupil?
Who is Mr Rochester?
I thought Thornfield Hall belonged to you.
Forgive me -
Thank you.
What a beautiful house.
Where did you live Adele, before you came to Thornfield?
Her mother has passed away.
Well - that would be lovely.
Adele is going to show us her accomplishments.
Who's there?
Who sleeps up here?
I heard someone.
A laugh. Someone laughed.
I'm not in need of tea, thank you.
Oh, Mrs Fairfax, no. I'm so thankful to be at Thornfield.
I wish a woman could have action in her life, like a man. It agitates me to pain that the sky-
Can I do anything, sir?
Are you injured, sir?
If you are hurt and want help I can fetch someone from the village. I'm on my way there to post a letter.
Thornfield Hall.
Mr Rochester's.
No, I've never seen him.
I am the governess, sir.
No.
Oh?
I have to change?
But all my dresses are the same.
Thank you.
Yes, sir.
Pardon?

I was brought up by my Aunt, Mrs Reed of Gateshead, in a house far finer than this. At ten years old I went to Lowood school where I received as good an education as I could hope for. I have no tale of woe, sir.
Dead.
No.
She cast me off, sir.
Because I was burdensome and she disliked me.
Yes.
Eight years.
Yes sir.
Out of my head.
Yes sir.
The evening star.
What for?
Why?
How, sir?
No sir.
I was too plain; I beg your pardon.
Mr Rochester, it was a blunder.
You have other qualities, sir.
Not at all.
What about, sir?
How can I introduce a subject when I don't know what'll interest you?
Yet you'd command me to speak?
I don't think you have a right to command me just because you're older. Your claim to superiority depends on the use you've made of your time and experience.
There are few masters who'd trouble to enquire whether their paid subordinates were hurt by their commands.
I'd never mistake informality for insolence, sir. One, I rather like. The other, nothing free born should ever submit to - even for a salary.
You've clearly not spent much time in the company of schoolgirl governesses. I'm the same plain kind of bird as all the rest, with my couple of accomplishments and my common tale of woe.
How?
Are you a villain then, sir?
Then you'll degenerate still more.
I'm reminding you of your own words; remorse is the poison of life.
I don't know. To speak truth, I don't understand you at all.
Sir, I find the conversation has got out of my depth.
I'm not afraid.
I've simply no wish to talk nonsense.
Just as it turns to come down -
Mademoiselle has got to rest.
Have mercy, Adele. Play with Pilot for a while.
Is our game disturbing you, sir?
To fall in love, sir?
Does it?
Were you dashed to pieces, Mr Rochester?
But you took her on?
Who's there?
Wake up! Wake up! Sir!
It is I, Jane Eyre, sir.
For heaven's sake get up. Somebody has plotted something; you must find out who. I'll light the lamp -
I heard a laugh outside my door loud enough to wake me. I opened it. Someone was running towards the third floor.
And a candle was left burning in the middle of the floor. Shall I fetch Mrs Fairfax, sir?
Then I'll wake John and Martha.
Only the candle on the ground.
Yes.
There's a woman who sews here; Grace Poole - She laughs in that way, I think.
Yes, sir.
Good-night.
You said I should go.
What am I to do then, sir?
There is no debt.
Good night then, sir.
I'm cold.
What's happened here?
I did. I heard a strange laugh.
I was not.
Has Mr Rochester not sent for us today?
Oh?
Nothing. Speak in English, please.
Thank you, girls. You may go.
Not at all. I'm getting on very well.
I hardly have time to notice it.
A few months ago I had nothing. I was wretched. Now I have a home and work; free and honest. I wonder at the goodness of God and at the generosity of my friends.
It's what I mean to do.
Thank you.
Why were you intensely miserable?
You could have been happy.
Yes.
What's the matter?
May I assist you, Mrs Fairfax?
Excuse me, miss.
What is it, darling?
Not me, surely.
He was being polite.
May I present Miss Adele Varens?
I am tired, sir.
You seemed engaged, sir.
Teaching Adele.
I am well.
Can I help you sir?
Turn them out of the room sir, if I could.
I should care nothing about it.
For the sake of any friend who deserved it.
It seems to me a splendid mansion, sir.
Will Grace Poole stay here now?
But sir -
Yes sir.
Yes sir.
I'd do anything for you sir, anything that was right.
Excuse me, sir.
If you please, I want leave of absence for a week or two.
This is from my old nurse, Bessie.
She's been asking for me. I parted from her very badly and I can't neglect her wishes now.
Sir, it seems you are soon to be married.
Adele should go to school.
And I must seek another situation.
And sir? Forgive me but I have had no wages as yet.
Fifteen pounds.
That's too much.
I cannot.
Now you owe me five.
Not a whit, sir. You are not to be trusted at all.
Bessie... I'm not too late? How is Mrs Reed?
Shall I see her now?
Aunt Reed? It is Jane Eyre. You sent for me, and here I am.
Why do you hate her so?
I am Jane Eyre, Aunt.
We are alone.
Please, don't think of it -

'Madam, will you have the goodness to send me the address of my niece, Jane Eyre. I desire her to come to me at Madeira. Fortune has blessed my endeavours and as I am childless I wish to adopt her and bequeath her at my death whatever I may have to leave. Yours, John Eyre, Madeira.'  Jane is stunned.
This is dated three years ago.
Forgive me.
I would have loved you if you'd let me.
Please, let us be reconciled.
Then love me or hate me as you will. You have my full and free forgiveness. Now ask for God's -
My mother.
Why ever was I so afraid?
My dear uncle, some years ago, my Aunt Reed mistakenly informed you that I had died.
I am writing to tell you that I am very much alive and living at Thornfield Hall, where I am currently governess to the ward of Mr Edward Fairfax Rochester -
I have been with my aunt sir, who is dead.
Thank you Mr Rochester. I'm strangely glad to get back again to you. Wherever you are is my home.
Then we must accept it. He'll soon bring home his bride.
I'll be sad to leave it.
Have you found me a new situation, sir?
Connaught?
It is a long way away, sir.
From here. From you.
I wish I could. I wish I'd never come here. I love Thornfield -
Because of your bride.
But you will have.
Then I must go.
Do you think I could stay to become nothing to you? Am I an automaton, a machine without feelings?
Do you think that because I am poor, obscure, plain and little that I am soulless and heartless?

I have as much soul as you and full as much heart. I'm not speaking to you through mortal flesh. It's my spirit that addresses your spirit as if we'd passed through the grave and stood at God's feet, equal - as we are.
Let me go.
I'm a free human being with an independent will, which I now exert to leave you.
Are you mocking me?
Entirely.
Not a whit.
Your bride is Miss Ingram -
Are you in earnest?
You wish me to be your wife?
You love me.
Then sir, I will marry you.
I must go.
Good night.
Yes.
Am I a monster? Is it so impossible that Mr Rochester should love me?
Thank you.
It is I, Jane Eyre sir.
It can never be, sir. Human beings were not meant to enjoy complete happiness on this earth.
Oh, no sir -
I don't want jewels -
Then you won't know me. I'll not be Jane Eyre any longer but an ape in a harlequin's jacket. Put them away.
I'm naturally proud. And hard and flinty. You ought to know what sort of bargain you've made while you've still got time to rescind it. I want only one thing from you, Mr Rochester.
Your regard.
Adele?
Adele, is that you?
I'm afraid.
It was not Grace Poole.
I was not asleep.
I know what I saw.
Thank you.
I cannot.
I'm tired and sick. I need some water.
Much better, sir. I shall be well again soon.
All is changed, sir. I must change too.
Sir - you speak of her with hate -
I do.
No.
You can't.
I must leave you, sir.
I do love you - But I mustn't show it or speak it ever again. I must begin a new existence -
You have a wife already.
I earnestly pity you, sir.
Do not say it -
I can not.
How?
You once told me that hiring a mistress is the next worse thing to buying a slave.
I would not degrade you by having you live with a slave.
I do.
I do.
I would.
It would be to obey you. I care for myself.
The more alone, the more friendless, unsustained I am, the more I must respect myself -
I must listen to myself -
Let me go -
God help me!
Edward.
Mr St John - What on earth brings you away from your hearth on a night like this? Has anything happened? There's no bad news I hope?
You are recklessly rash about your own health.
Why are you come?
I mean on a night like this -
Please...
Mr Rivers! -
Since you know so much, perhaps you can tell me how he is.
Mr Rochester; how is he?
The solicitor - Mr Briggs - does he have any news of Mr Rochester?
What does he want with me?
What?
How much am I worth?
Twenty thousand pounds?
There must be some mistake. It's two thousand, surely.
Why did Mr Briggs write to you?
Yes.
St John Eyre -
Your mother was my father's sister?
My uncle John was your uncle John?
So you, Diana and Mary -
Oh, I am glad! - I am glad!

Of no moment? You have sisters and maybe don't care for a cousin but I have nobody. I have been alone, always. And now three relations are born into my world full grown. Oh, I am glad. You, who saved my life -
Write to Diana and Mary. Tell them to hand in notice and come home. They will have five thousand each and so will you.
Don't put me out of patience, cousin. I am rational enough.
And you cannot imagine - family -
You are not reluctant to own me, are you?
Di, you are very provoking.
Am I not being useful?
Beyond to what?
So soon? -
I'm not fit for it. I have no vocation.
St John have mercy. I feel my mind shrinking -

I used to long for a life of action, to overleap the horizon, to move in the world of men. Maybe God is giving me this. And what is there for me here? Pain and longing for what can't be. I don't know how long I would survive in India. My frame isn't strong. But I'll go with you, if I may go free.
You and I had better not marry.
Because I am your sister.
Conditionally - as your curate.
I must have my heart and mind free, my own self to turn to. I couldn't become part of you -
Enough of love?
St John, I scorn your idea of love. I scorn the counterfeit sentiment you offer and I scorn you when you offer it!
Forgive me but the very name of love is an apple of discord between us. My dear cousin, please abandon your scheme of marriage.
Do not be angry with me please.
I cannot come as your wife.
If I were to marry you, you'd kill me. You're killing me now.
You'd kill me without drawing any blood or receiving on your conscience any stain of crime.
You'd experience no pain - but I tell you it would kill me!

Because I would inevitably come to conceive love for you, because you are so talented and good, because there is such grandeur in your look. You wouldn't want this strange and torturing love; if I showed it you would find it unbecoming. And my lot would be wretched.
You're a good man, but you forget the feelings of little people. We'd better keep out of your way lest you trample us.
If I were sure; if I were certain -
Oh God, what is it?
I am coming!
Wait for me!
Where are you?
They sent me from the inn. I've been up at the house -
Is he dead?
Tell me - please -
He stayed at Thornfield?
Why?
I had dreaded worse. I'd dreaded he was mad.
Where is he?
Martha is in the kitchen, sir.
Pilot knows me. Will you have some more water? I've spilt half the glass.
And her voice.
My Edward, I am Jane Eyre: I have found you out. I am come back to you.
I've been with good people; far better than you, quite more refined and exalted.
And I'm an independent woman. My uncle in Madeira died and left me five thousand pounds -
I'm here. I'm home. I am where I love best.
I conscientiously believe so, sir.
But I see that you're turning into a lion. It's time someone undertook to rehumanise you.
I know.
And the worst of it is, I'm in danger of loving you too well for this, and making too much of you.
Very. But you always were, you know.
All of God's creatures must die.
You did your duty in excluding her. Let me do mine in admitting her.
I don't know; I found her at the door.
She's no vagrant; I'm sure of it.
Ask her her name.
Can we send for anyone? Who are your people?
Diana, Mary help me get her upstairs...
I'm sure we'll find she's simply had a misunderstanding with her people. I hope she's not done anything deplorable; there's nothing so sad as a fallen young woman.
She's not at all handsome.
Ill or well, she'll always be plain.
Who can we send for to help you?
Do you mean to say that you are absolutely without home and without friends?
How did you come to be roaming the moors, Miss Elliott?
How are we to help you if we know nothing about you?
Why did you leave your place of employment?
What did you do?
Why did you start?
Why not?
Merciful Jesus, enlighten thou me with the brightness of thine inward light...
And take away all darkness from the habitation of my heart...
Join me to thyself with an inseparable band of love... For thou, even thou alone, dost satisfy him that loveth thee...
And without thee all things are vain and empty. Amen.
You wish to be independent of my charity?
My sisters have always taken pleasure in keeping injured birds but I'm more inclined to put you in a way of keeping yourself -
This school you were at, Miss Elliot, this charitable institution; what did it prepare you for?
Was it a thorough education?
How fierce I am, Miss Elliott.
I found you a situation some days ago but I've delayed telling you because the work is lowly and I fear you'll scorn it.
As I am poor and obscure, the help I can offer is of the meanest sort.

When I took over the parish two years ago it had no school. I opened one for boys; I now intend to open one for girls. The school mistress will have a two-roomed cottage paid for by local benefactors and she will receive fifteen pounds a year. You can see how humble, how ignoble it is.
But you comprehend me? It's a village school - cottagers daughters. What will you do with all your fine accomplishments?
Do you find the work too hard?
Do you feel the solitude an oppression?
Then perhaps your accommodations have disappointed you. They are in truth scanty enough -
What you had left before I met you, I don't know. But I counsel you to resist firmly every temptation to look back.
We can overcome every kind of human weakness. A year ago I was myself intensely miserable. I considered my life was so wretched that it must be changed - or I would die.
A year ago, I was weak enough to fall in love.

Don't pity me; I have no compassion whatsoever for you. I regarded this love as a fever of the flesh; not a thing that would ever touch my soul. I scorned the weakness, fought hard against it - and won.
I could have listened to temptation, sunk down in the silken snare and known a feverish and delusive bliss. I could have squandered my future upon it.
A slave in a fool's paradise? I'd rather my life had purpose -
Is this yours?
Nothing in the world.
Good night.
How easily alarmed you are.
The snow was up to my waist at one point.
Nonsense.
An inhospitable question.
I got tired of my mute books and empty rooms. Besides I've been told half a story and I'm most impatient to find out the end.

Twenty years ago, a poor curate fell in love with a rich man's daughter and married her. She was disowned by her family and two years later the rash pair were both dead. They left a daughter which charity received into her lap - as cold as that snow drift I almost stuck fast in. Charity carried the friendless thing to the house of its rich maternal relations. It was reared by an aunt-in-law; I come to names now - Mrs Reed of Gateshead.
Mrs Reed kept the orphan ten years and at the end of that time she was sent to Lowood school.
It seems her career there was very honourable. She became a teacher like yourself, and left it, like yourself, to be a governess. She undertook the education of the ward of a certain Mr Rochester -

I can guess your feelings but hear me to the end. Of Mr Rochester's character I know nothing but he professed to offer honourable marriage to this young girl and at the very altar she discovered that he had a wife yet alive. His subsequent conduct is a matter of pure conjecture but when the governess was enquired after it was discovered that she had fled Thornfield Hall and no trace of her has since been found. Now isn't that an odd tale?
Who?
I'm ignorant of all concerning him.
Well, since you won't ask the governess's name, I must tell you. I have it written down here in black and white.
A solicitor named Briggs wrote to me of a Jane Eyre. I knew a Jane Elliott. This paper resolved my suspicion into certainty.
Are you not going to enquire why he has gone to such lengths to find you?
Merely to tell you that your uncle, Mr John Eyre of Madeira, is dead; that he has left you all his property and that you are now rich.
You are rich; quite an heiress.
Your fortune is vested in the English funds; Briggs has the will and all the necessary documents. You can enter on immediate possession.
Your forehead unbends at last; I thought you were turning to stone. Perhaps now you will ask how much you are worth.
Oh a trifle. Twenty thousand pounds - but what of that?
If you'd committed a murder and I'd found you out, you could scarcely look more aghast.
It's twenty. You look desperately miserable about it, I must say.
You see, that is the strange thing.
Then I'm you namesake. I was christened St John Eyre Rivers.

My mother had two brothers, one was a clergyman, your father, the other was John Eyre of Madeira. Mr Briggs wrote to inform us that the clergyman's daughter was lost. I have been able to find her out; that is all.
Yes.
That is correct.
We are cousins, yes.
Here you are neglecting essential points to pursue trifles. You were utterly downhearted when I told you that you were rich and now, for a matter of no moment, you are deliriously happy.
You must try to tranquillise your feelings.
I've told you the news too quickly.
This is acting on first impulse.
Jane, I will be your brother.
Good night.
Good night.
You are wasted here.
You should look beyond Moor House, beyond the selfish calm and comfort of affluence.
I go to India in six weeks.
I can see what your gifts are and why they were given. Come with me.
God and nature intended you for a missionary's wife. You are formed for labour not for love. I want to claim you - not for my pleasure but for God's service.
You're far too humble.

Don't be afraid. You are diligent, faithful, docile, courageous, gentle and heroic. Cease to mistrust yourself. I trust you unreservedly. Let me give you time to think. But know this; in you, I recognise a fellow soul, a soul that would revel in the flame and excitement of sacrifice.
Free?
Why not?
But you'll go with me.
Jane, I don't need a curate; I need a wife.

A part of me you must become or the whole bargain is void. How can I, a man not yet thirty take out to India a girl of nineteen, unless she is my wife? Don't offer God half a sacrifice. He must have all.
Yes, quite enough.
I've uttered nothing that deserves scorn.
No; and if you reject it, it's not me you deny but God.
We are friends. I hope we can be more.
Why this refusal? It makes no sense!
I'd kill you? I am killing you?
What nonsense is this?
Why?
Jane...
I wouldn't trample you. You'd walk at my side towards God's altar. He'd be your solace, heaven your reward. We seek to do the greatest work, to open death's gates, to save souls.
Give up your heart to Him. He is love.
What have you heard? What can you see?
St John, who is it?
Hannah, some water.
Mary.
Please, tell us how we may help you.
She has a peculiar face; I rather like it.
She's so ill, St John.
Where do you come from, Miss Elliott?
Don't upset her, St John. She must not be interrogated so.
We did wonder. We mean no offence but you have a certain look. Mary and I work as governesses too.
We came home only for our father's funeral.
That's enough for now, St John.
You haven't given us your real name?
Welcome to our table, Miss Elliott.
You're not fit enough to work.
It's a shame she has no choice of helpers, St John, and must put up with such crusty people as you.
It'll be a hard parting for us. We may not see him again for years.
St John burns with talents and ambition. But he lacks the means for advancement here. Our poverty thwarts him at every turn and so he has chosen to lay all his gifts on God's altar.
Inexorable as death.
St John, what are you going to offer her? Not washerwoman, I hope?
You call Jane your sister but you don't treat her as such. You should kiss her too.
She's as white as death.
She's worn to nothing. She looks like a spectre. St John, if you hadn't taken her in, we would have fallen upon her dead body in the morning.
She's awake.
Look at the suffering in her eyes. They're like dark pools -
Jane Elliot.
Diana, didn't I say so? Didn't I say she was a governess?
We are currently trying to teach ourselves German, so we may find better positions.
He died three weeks ago.
You must rest, Miss Elliott.
It's wonderful to see you on your feet, Miss Jane.
We've lived here all our lives but the house must be shut up now.
We can't afford to keep it on.
He means to be a missionary. He's going to India to do Gods's work.
This quiet parish will never do for him; he almost raves in his restlessness. It breaks our hearts.
We've tried to persuade him to stay but in some things our brother is - he is -
We are now without father. We'll soon be without home and brother.
Jane?
You are doing something already.
St John -
See how skilled Jane is.
She is better than any drawing master we have ever had.
Jane Eyre!
Jane Eyre! Where are you?
Come out, rat. I know you are in here. Come out now and I won't punish you.
Rat.
I have been looking for you these last ten minutes.
Say forgive me, Master Reed.
Who gave you permission to read my book?
Everything in this house is mine.
That's for the look you had on your face. You bad animal.
I shall tell mother -
Mamma! Mamma! There's a rat! Rat!
So, Rat, you're being sent away.
That's for the look you had on your face.
For shame, hitting your master.
What we do is for your own good.
Miss Eyre what is it?
Have you seen something?
But she screamed so loud ma'am.
You're such a queer, solitary little thing. If only you could make yourself more appealing.
I don't dislike you Miss; I'm fonder of you than of anyone.
Miss Jane -
You take good care of her.
Bless you! - I knew you'd come.
I'll take you up directly. But look at you. What a lady you've become.
If you don't sit still you must be tied down!
You're worse than us servants. We work for our keep; you do nothing. Pray for forgiveness Miss Eyre or something bad will come down that chimney and fetch you away.
Bessie, I gave orders that she was to be left in the red room until I came.
It is play-acting. Let her go. I know your tricks Jane Eyre and I abhor such artifice. Loose Bessie's hands, child.
You will now stay here an hour longer.
And only when you are perfectly submissive will I let you out.
Silence. This violence is repulsive.
Get back!
I've been her sole benefactress and her kindest friend. But she shows no gratitude and brings nothing but discord into my house.
She's an orphan. Her mother was my late husband's sister. On his deathbed he exhorted me to care for her. I have always treated her as one of my own.
If you accept her at Lowood school Mr Brocklehurst, keep a strict eye on her. Her worst fault is a tendency to deceit. I'm sorry to tell you that Jane Eyre is a liar.
I wish her to be made useful, to be kept humble.
And as for its vacations, it must spend them all at Lowood.
How dare you speak in this manner.
You wouldn't dare.
Children must be corrected for their faults.
But you are passionate.
No one knows the trouble I have with that child. Such a burden.

Her mother. Reed's sister - his beloved. When news came of her death he wept like a fool. Sent for the baby. Sickly thing - not strong like mine. But Reed loved it. Kept it by his bed. Made me vow to bring the creature up. Why did he not love mine?
Who are you?
You. Is there no one in the room?
I've twice done you wrong. I broke the vow I made to Reed -
I am dying; I must get it out!
Open that box. Take out the letter. Read it.
Because I wrote and told him you had died of typhus at Lowood school. You fury. You were born to be my torment. I'll never forget how you turned on me and raged.
You called the names of the dead down upon me. I was afraid.
You cursed me.
My life has been cursed.
There is no sight so sad and so deplorable as that of a wicked little girl. Do you know, Jane Eyre, where the wicked go after death?
And what is hell, can you tell me that?
And should you like to fall into that pit and be burning there forever?
What must you do to avoid it?
What is her parentage?
All liars will have their portion in the lake burning with fire and brimstone. She shall be watched, Mrs Reed.
You can rest assured dear lady that we mortify our girls in the sentiments of vanity and pride.
We shall root out the wickedness in this small, ungrateful plant.
I might have known. The new girl.
It is my duty dear children, to warn you that this girl is not one of God's own lambs.
She is a castaway and an alien in his flock and you must be on your guard against her. For this child... is a liar!
This is the pedestal of infamy -
I hear you are to leave us, Miss Eyre.
What's your name, child?
You are very young to be sent alone, Jane Eyre.
Come here, Girls.
I shall investigate Mr Brocklehurst's claims against you, Jane. And unless they are proved, you will be exonerated.
Also, I understand you girls have had no food today.
This is the result of semi-
Jane...
Burns, Helen Burns!
You're a slattern and a disgrace!
Come now, don't cry.
Mr Brocklehurst is not a God.
If your own conscience approves you, then so will I.
Bear what?
I'm a trial to Miss Scatcherd.
You'd just be punished even more.
You're not ugly. Do you know what is inside you?
The spark of your spirit, the principle of light and thought, pure and bright, as perfect as anything created.
Your soul. Your soul is beautiful, your soul has value - more value than anything on earth.
Yes. God sees your beauty. Even as you stand on that stool, there is an invisible world around you, a kingdom of spirits. It is everywhere. Angels see your pain.
Do you not believe in angels?
Is it you, Jane? Have you come to say goodbye?
I'm very happy. I am going home.
My father has a new wife. He'll not miss me much.
To my future home, where all is light. I am going to God.
Don't be sad. I will escape great suffering by dying young.
I don't have any talent to make my way in life. I should be always at fault. But God is my friend. He loves me.
He is saving me.
I feel like I could sleep now. I like to have you near -
You're so warm and alive. Jane, you have a passion for living.
He is yours.
Write to the governors. You must.
If Jane Eyre of Lowood School...
...Who advertised in the Yorkshire Herald, possesses the acquirements mentioned...

...And if she is in a position to give satisfactory references, a situation can be offered where there is but one pupil, a little girl under ten years of age and where the salary is thirty pounds a year.
Jane Eyre is requested to send references and all particulars to Mrs Fairfax at Thornfield Hall.
How do you do, my dear? What a long and tedious journey you must have had of it. John is quite the slowest driver in the county. You must be cold to the bone.
Indeed I am; come and warm yourself in here.
Your poor hands must be quite numb; here, let me help you.
Leah, make a little hot port and cut a sandwich or two.
Draw nearer the fire. John is taking your trunk up to your room.
I've put you at the back of the house; I hope you don't mind. The rooms at the front have much finer furniture but they are so gloomy and solitary I think.

I'm so glad you are come. To be sure this is a fine old house but I must confess that in winter one can feel a little dreary and alone. Leah is a very nice girl and John and Martha good people too, but they are servants - and one cannot talk to them on terms of equality.
Who?
Oh you mean Miss Varens; Mr Rochester's ward. She is to be your pupil.
Why, the owner of Thornfield.
Oh bless you child, what an idea.
There is a distant connection between Mr Rochester and I - his mother was a Fairfax - but I'd never presume on it. Heavens, me, owner of Thornfield?
We shall have a cheerful house this winter...
With Miss Varens here - and with you - we'll have quite a merry time of it.

I'm sure that last winter - and what a severe one - if it didn't rain it snowed and if it didn't snow it blew a gale - last winter I declare that not a soul came to the house from November to February.
I got quite melancholy night after night alone. When spring finally came I thought it a great relief that I hadn't gone distracted.
Here.
Good night, my dear. I hope you'll be comfy.
Mr Rochester's visits here are always unexpected. He doesn't like to arrive and find everything all swathed up, so I keep it in constant readiness.
Would you ask her about her parents? Mr Rochester's neglected to tell me anything about her.
How very French...
Here. For you.
No one. This part of the house is quite empty, except for you and me.
You can't have done.
Oh - that must be Grace Poole.
Miss Eyre has heard a laugh.
I thought I might find you up here.
But it's a quiet life, isn't it?
Well now - exercise is a great cure for anything, they say.
I have some letters to post; will you take them?
Mr Rochester is here.
Go and change your frock; he wishes to meet you.
Oh yes - I always dress for the evening when Mr Rochester is here.
You must have one that is better?
Here is Miss Eyre, Sir.
Sir?
Sorry to disturb. He's asked for your art.
He wishes to have it.
To show to his company, I should think. Is this it here? Thank you.
We'll open it together, shall we?
Let's try it on, shall we?
Why, he's gone away. Were you not aware? He left after breakfast.
He's gone to The Leas, Mr Eshton's place, about ten miles from here. I believe Blanche Ingram is there. She's a great favourite of his.
I saw her two years ago when Mr Rochester had a party here. Oh, she was a beauty; I daresay the most elegant girl I've ever seen.
I was quite surprised he didn't make a proposal. Perhaps that is his intention now.
He's back in three days he says -
I'll get started. I'll go to the George. No, I'll tell Martha...
Thank you.
Tonight. He wants you both in the drawing room after dinner.
It's his particular wish.
I'm instructed to tell you that if you resist, he'll come up and get you himself. You needn't stay long. Just let him see you and then slip away. Don't worry; no one'll look at you.
A gentleman has arrived to see you, sir.
He says he's travelled a long way, from Spanish Town, Jamaica -
And indeed I think he must have come from some hot country because he won't take off his coat.
Mr Richard Mason. He says you're old friends. I've put him in the morning room.
Have I done wrong?
We're expecting the announcement very soon. He went down to London only last week to buy her a new carriage.
Have you accepted him?
Well I never would have thought.

No, I've long noticed that you were a sort of pet of his. But you're so young and so little acquainted with men. I don't want to grieve you child, but let me put you on your guard. Gentlemen in his position...
Come in, come in.
No, no. Mr Rochester still lives.
Why did you run away in the night like that? I would have helped. I would have helped.
He sought you as if you were a lost and precious jewel. He didn't rest.
Didn't leave the house...
Shut himself up like a hermit. He only went out at night, when he walked like a ghost through the grounds.
It was harvest time when it happened. No one knows how she got out.
My theory is that when Mrs Poole was asleep, having taken too much of the gin and water...
... The mad lady must have stolen her keys and let herself out.
He didn't leave the house until everyone was out. Some say it was a just judgement on him for having her confined there all those years but for my part, I pity him.
He's alive child, but many think he'd be better off dead.

When he was taken out from under the ruins, a beam had fallen in such a way as to protect him, partly - but his eye was taken out and his left hand so crushed that he lost it. The other eye inflamed and - he is blind. He's blind.
I know... it's a terrible thing.
Sophie has been crying because no one understands. Nobody can speak to us except for Mr Rochester and he has gone away.
With Maman - but she is gone to the Holy Virgin now.
Maman used to teach me to dance and say verses. When gentlemen came to see her I used to dance for them or sit on their knees and sing. May I sing for you now?
Me! It is me!
Tonight I will have my cadeaux.
Monsieur!
Ma boite, ma boite!
Oh Ciel! Que c'est beau!
Monsieur, je vous remercie mille fois de votre bonte...
That is how Maman used to say, is it not?
Because I start to win!
Mademoiselle - Il faut jouer -
Qu'avez vous mademoiselle?
They're here! They're here!
She sing like Maman.
Bon jour, mesdames, monsieurs.
Mademoiselle...
What the deuce -
Hellfire.
Pilot, get down! GET DOWN I SAY!
Get back.
Mesrour. Mesrour.
Damnation.
Where do you come from?
Whose house is that?
Do you know Mr Rochester?
You're not a servant there...
The governess.
Deuce take me, I had forgotten.
The governess.
Have you got an umbrella I can use as a stick?
Then try to get hold of his bridle and lead him to me.
If you would be so kind...
Perhaps it would be easier to bring me to the horse. Come here.
Forgive me. I must beg of you to come here.
Mesrour.
Thank you.
Now, make haste with your letter.
Let her sit.
I have examined Adele and I find you've taken great pains with her. She's not bright, she has no talents - yet in a short time she's made much improvement.
You've been resident here three months?
And from whence do you hail; what's your tale of woe?
All governesses have a tale of woe; what's yours?
Where are your parents?
Do you remember them?
And why are you not with Mrs Reed of Gateshead now?
Why?
Lowood; that's a charity school, isn't it?
How long did you survive there?
No tale of woe...
Don't trouble yourself to give her a character. I'll judge for myself. She began by felling my horse.
I have her to thank for this sprain.
Adele has brought me these; are they yours?
Where did you get your copies?
That head I now see on your shoulders?
Who's this?
Why did you bewitch my horse?
Ah, there she is...
Take it away you genuine daughter of Paris and amuse yourself with disembowelling it.
Miss Eyre. Sit there.
I'm not fond of children.
Nor do I particularly enjoy simple-minded old ladies. But you might suit me - if you would.
By distracting me from the mire of my thoughts.
Precisely.
And that is how she charmed my English gold out of my English breeches pocket.
Your gaze is very direct, Miss Eyre? D'you think me handsome?
Just so; other qualities... When I was your age I was a felling enough fellow. I might have been insulted then. You're blushing Miss Eyre.
And though you're not pretty any more than I am handsome, I must say it becomes you.
And now I see you're fascinated by the flowers on the rug.
I'd like to draw you out. Come, speak to me.
The choice of subject is entirely yours.
The fact is, Miss Eyre, I don't wish to treat you like an inferior.
Well I probably have a right to be a little abrupt and exacting on the grounds of my superiority in age. There must be twenty years between us and a century's advance in experience.
I've made indifferent use of both. And this is why I sit, galled by my own thoughts - and order you to divert me. Are you very hurt by my tone of command?
Oh yes... paid subordinate; I'd forgotten the salary. Well on that mercenary ground, will you consent to speak with me as my equal - without thinking that the request arises from insolence?
Humbug. Most free-born things would submit to anything for a salary. But I mentally shake hands with you for your answer.
Not three in three thousand schoolgirl governesses would have answered me as you've just done.
I envy you.
Your openness, your clear conscience, your unpolluted mind.
I'm a trite commonplace sinner, hackneyed in all the dissipations that the rich and worthless try to put on life.

When I was your age, fate dealt me a blow. I was - cursed with a burden to carry through life. I lacked the wisdom to remain cool and I turned desperate. Dread remorse, Miss Eyre. It is the poison of life.
And since happiness is denied me, I've a right to get pleasure in its stead. And I will get it, cost what it may.
Are you preaching to me?
But, Miss Eyre, if the pleasure I was seeking was sweet and fresh; if it was an inspiration; if it wore the robes of an angel of light... what then?
My heart has long been a charnel house. Perhaps it'll transform into a shrine.
You're afraid of me because I talk like a sphynx.
Yes you are.
If you did it would be in such a grave, quiet manner that I would mistake it for sense. Do you never laugh, Miss Eyre?

Only rarely, perhaps. But you're not naturally austere, any more than I'm naturally vicious. I can see in you the glance of a curious sort of bird through the close set bars of a cage: a vivid, restless, resolute captive. Were it but free, it would soar. Cloud high.
On the contrary. I like your game.

I've been arranging a point with my destiny, Miss Eyre. My destiny stood up there by that chimney, like one of the hags who appeared to Macbeth. 'You like Thornfield?' She said. 'Like it if you dare'.
But Thornfield is my home and I shall like it!
Get back! Keep at a distance child, or go in!

She's the daughter of an opera dancer, Celine Varens. Celine was a beauty and she professed to love me. Her ardour was so great that, ugly as I am, I believed myself her idol. So I installed in her in a hotel, gave her servants, gowns cashmeres, diamonds - in short, I was an idiot.
You've never felt love, have you Miss Eyre? Your soul still sleeps.
You're still floating gently in the stream of life, unaware of the rocks ahead waiting to dash you to pieces.
Not by Celine. How can one ever truly love a woman one has paid for?
It ended when I visited her unexpectedly one night and caught her with her handsome, charmless lover. I overheard her waxing lyrical on all my defects - she was mercenary, heartless, senseless.

Some years later, I heard that Celine had abandoned the brat, disappeared to Italy and left it destitute. So I lifted it from the mud and slime of Paris and brought it here, to grow up clean in the wholesome soil of an English country garden. My one good work in a sea of countless sins.
You listen, Miss Eyre, as if it was the most usual thing in the world for a man like me to tell stories of his opera-mistresses to an inexperienced girl like you. Adele?
Forgive me; for keeping Miss Eyre from your game for so long.
Who's there?
What in the name of all the elves in Christendom have you done with me?
Light the lamp at your peril.
What the deuce can she do?
Not at all. Stay here. You're shivering.
I have to go to the third floor.
Did you see anything when you opened your chamber door?
But you heard a laugh?
Have you heard that laugh before?
Just so. Grace Poole - you have guessed it. Well, you're no talking fool; please say nothing about this.
I will account for this state of affairs. Go back to your room and say nothing.
Is that how you're going to leave me?
Jane, fire is a horrible death. You have saved my life. Don't walk past me as if we were strangers.
At least... shake hands.
I have a pleasure in owing you my life.

I knew you would do me good in some way. I saw it in your eyes when I first beheld you. Their expression did not - did not strike delight into my very inmost being so, for nothing. People talk of natural sympathies... You.
So you will leave me?
Go.
Good evening.
May I?
Yes.
You're right; I'm not.
She was left on my hands.
She has a governess.
Donna Bianca, I give you beauty.
So a Levantine pirate would do for you?
Why did you leave the room?
Why didn't you come and speak to me? I haven't seen you for weeks.
What have you been doing while I've been gone?
You look pale.
You're depressed; your eyes are shining with tears. What's the meaning of this?
Who?
Spanish Town...
Not at all. Please tell him I'll see him directly.
Oh Jane - Jane. This is a blow.
Jane, if all those people came and spat at me, what would you do?
And if they cast you out for adhering to me?
You'd dare censure for my sake?
Richard. How the devil are you?
I'm here, be composed.
A servant has had a nightmare, that's all. She's an excitable, nervous person and has taken a fit with fright.
Now I must see you back into your rooms because until the house is settled, she can't be properly looked after.
Miss Ingram, ladies, please return to your nests like the doves that you are. You'll take cold for certain if you stay in this icy gallery any longer.
Come this way. Make no noise.
Be steady. I need you.
Wait.
Thank you, Mrs Poole.
Here. Bring the candle.
No.
It was folly to attempt the interview tonight and alone.
It makes me impatient to hear you.
Think of her as dead, dead and buried. Say nothing!
I am going for a doctor. I must leave you here with him. Sponge the blood away when it returns.
Jane, make sure the way is clear.
I'll ride over tomorrow to see how you do. Goodbye, Richard.
I do my best and have done it and will do it!
Come, Jane. That house is a dungeon, don't you feel it?
It is slime and cobwebs.
Oh yes, don't trouble your head about her.
Grace Poole is not the danger.
You've noticed my tender feelings for Miss Ingram?
Keep vigil with me again, the night before I marry. For now you've met my lovely one and you know her.
A strapper, a real strapper; big and buxom...
And if I ever bid you do what was wrong, you'd turn to me, quiet and pale and say 'I cannot do it.' And you'd be as immutable as a fixed star.
What to do?
What good can you do her?
Promise me you won't stay long.
What of it?
To get her out of my bride's way who might otherwise trample her?
At your peril you advertise. Trust it to me. I'll find you a good situation in time.
How much do I owe you?
Here's fifty.
Take your wages.
Then I only have a ten.
Just so. Come back for it quickly.
Do you trust me to keep it, Jane?
There you are.
Just like one of your tricks to steal into your home along with the twilight. Where the deuce have you been this last month?
A true Janian reply. If I dared I'd touch you, to see if you were real...
Go home - stay your wandering feet at a friend's threshold.
Come and look at this fellow, Jane.
Look at his wings. He looks West Indian - I have never seen one like him, here. There; flown.
Thornfield is a pleasant place in summer, isn't it?
Yes, but it can't be helped. I soon hope to be a bridegroom.
A situation, yes of course. It's the least I can do for a faithful paid subordinate such as yourself.
You'll like Ireland. They're such warm-hearted people, they say.
From what?
We've been good friends, Jane haven't we? But with the Irish sea between us you'd soon forget me.
Then why must you be torn from me?
I have no bride.
Yes, I will.
You must stay.
As we are.
Then let your will decide your destiny. I offer you my hand, my heart and a share of all this.
I ask you to pass through life at my side. Jane, you are my equal and my likeness. It is you I intend to marry.
Do you doubt me?
You have no faith in me?
You little sceptic.
What love have I for Miss Ingram?
I must have you for my own.
I swear it.
I do.
It will atone. It will atone.
Good night. Good night.
Is this my pale elf? This sunny faced girl with the radiant eyes?
Soon to be Jane Rochester.
Let the fairy tale begin.
This morning I wrote to my banker in London to send certain jewels.
I will put the diamond chain around your neck myself -
I'll dress you in these satins -
Well for cool native impudence and pure innate pride, you haven't your equal.
And what's that?
It's your time now, little tyrant but it'll soon be mine and when I have seized you, to have and to hold, I'll attach you to a chain, like this...
What is it?
Jane, this is the only explanation.
You know how strange she is. What did she do to me? To Mason? In a state between sleeping and waking -
You noticed her entrance and her actions but you've ascribed to her an appearance different from her own. That was your nightmare -
I see you'd ask why I keep such a woman in my house. When we've been married a year and a day, I promise I'll tell you. Are you satisfied Jane? Do you accept my solution?
Dear God. It was only the veil...
Come.
Proceed.
Proceed.
Where is your proof?
That does not prove that my wife is still living.
How do you know?
Produce him or go to hell.
What have you to say?
This girl knew nothing. She thought all was fair and legal.
Come, Jane, come all of you and meet Mrs Poole's charming patient. Come and meet my wife.
Get back! Do not come near! Go, all of you - keep your congratulations - they come fifteen years too late!
This clothed hyena is my wife.
I was duped into marriage with this lunatic fifteen years ago.
My own demon, Bertha.
Five minutes more of that death-
No tears. Your heart has been weeping blood. Forgive me.
How could I? I am a worthless sinner. Don't spare me. Rain your tears up on me.
I deserve a hail of fire.
How are you now?
I know you. You are thinking.

Yes. There is no doubt that we both must change. I was wrong ever to keep you here; this narrow stone vault with its one real fiend. I'll shut it up. I'll pay Mrs Poole two hundred a year to care for its inmate and then no one will be harmed when she is prompted to burn people, to stab them, to bite the flesh from their bones -
It's not because she's mad that I hate her. If you were mad do you think that I'd hate you?

Then you know nothing about me, nothing about the way I love. Your mind is my treasure - and if it were broken it would be my treasure still. You are my sympathy, my better self, my angel. I will wrap my whole existence round you. Let us leave here tomorrow. Come with me - as my wife.
I'll pledge you my fidelity -
You'll live a happy, most innocent life -
Don't you love me?
Must be a part of me; that's what you mean. You are my wife, Jane.

I was tricked, duped into wedlock with that demon-hate, that harlot, that succubus upstairs. My father wanted her money and so I was sent to Spanish Town and the match was made. I hardly spoke with her. I was dazzled, ignorant, raw. My senses were besotted and I married her - gross, grovelling mole-eyed blockhead that I was.
I lived with her for four years.

I would have pulled the trigger, died in that tropical place but for a breeze which blew in from the sea and smelt of home. With it, I came to my senses. Bertha Antoinetta Mason had abused my long suffering, sullied my name, outraged my honour and blighted my youth. It was enough. At that moment, as I decided to live, she ceased to be my wife.

Only my father and brother knew of the marriage and by then they were both dead. I let my connection with her be buried in oblivion and I brought her here. I have seen that she's cared for as her condition demands and that is all that God and humanity asks.
Jane, it's not pity that I see in your face. It's not pity -
It is love.
I was wrong to deceive you. It was cowardly. I should have appealed to your spirit - as I do now - should have opened my life, described my hunger for a better existence -
You would be my equal.
I would make it so.
Not my mistress -
I said wife, my wife -
Do you really mean to leave me?
Jane...
Do you mean it now?
And now?
Oh Jane...
What friends would you offend by living with me? Who would be injured? Who would care?
Jane, it would not be wicked to love me...
Will you listen to me?
Will you hear reason?
Because if you won't I'll try violence.
I could bend you with my finger and thumb; a mere reed you feel in my hands.
But your eye; resolute, free. What ever I do with this cage I cannot get at you. And it is you, soul, that I want. Why don't you come of your own free will here, to my heart? Oh come, Jane, come -
You have never called me by my name. My name is Edward.
Jane.
Jane! Jane! Jane!
I can see the candles, Martha, at your side like a luminous glow.
Martha?
Martha, is that you?
Who's there?
If you are real, touch me.
Jane Eyre - Jane Eyre.
You're not lying dead in some ditch? Not an outcast among strangers?
She insults me -
This is real. This is practical.
You're altogether a human being, Jane?
I'm a sightless block -
Am I hideous, Jane?
Good day to you, miss.
Only master reading in his bed last night.
Fell asleep with his candle lit and the curtains got on fire.
It's hardly likely the master would laugh when he was in such danger. Perhaps you were dreaming.
Then you didn't think of opening your door and looking out?
Sir, you can't be bringing folk in here. It's madness.
Antoinetta?
She gets good wages, I'd guess?
She's a good hand, I daresay.
Doesn't she know?
Wish I had as good; not one fifth what Mrs Poole receives.
And she's laying it all by. I shouldn't wonder if she's saved enough to keep her independent.
Not everyone could do it, that's for sure, not even for the money.
Why, what a little puppet.
I thought you weren't fond of children?
Then what induced you to take charge of that little doll?
Why don't you send her to school?
You should hear mamma on the chapter of governesses. I had half a dozen in my day - all detestable, ridiculous incubi -
I said governesses.
I have just one word to say of the whole tribe; nuisance.
We shall have music - and new subject, if you please. Signor Eduardo, what shall it be?
Beauty? Why there's nothing new to be said. I give you back male beauty. Mamma, what's your idea of male beauty?
Oh, Tedo's quite typical of the young men of today. They're so absorbed in the pursuit of fashion that they've forgotten how to be men at all.
A woman who neglects herself is a blot on humanity. But a man should pay no heed to his looks.
A man should possess only strength and valour. He could be a gentleman or a highwayman. His beauty lies in his power.
As long as he resembled you.
I am serious. To my mind, a man is nothing without a spice of the devil in him.
Who is hurt?
What awful event has taken place?
Is there anything I might do?
Does that creeping creature want you?
Is this your ward, Mr Rochester?
Did you speak, my lily flower?
Oh, don't mention them; the very word makes me nervous! I've suffered a martyrdom from their incompetence and caprice. I thank heaven we're now done with them.
My son, of course.
Oh what is it?
What a love of a child.
Hear hear.
I say -
Where the devil is Rochester?
Fairfax...
Help! Rochester, for God's sake come!
Am I dying?
She bit me - while the knife was in - Bit me -
I thought I might have done some good.
She sucked the blood. Said she'd drain me - like a vampire -
Fairfax - Let her treated as tenderly as may be -
Good God -
She is at Thornfield Hall. I saw her there in April. I'm her brother.
I only wish I could have got here sooner. He'd not have bled so much.
Please, you must look.

I require and charge you both, as ye will answer at the dreadful day of judgement when the secrets of all hearts shall be revealed, that if either of you know any impediment why ye may not be lawfully joined together in matrimony, ye do now confess it.
Sir, you are in a sacred place -
Let us go. We have seen enough.
The marriage cannot go on. I declare the existence of an impediment.
The ceremony is quite broken off.
Mr Rochester has a wife now living.
I affirm and can prove that Edward Fairfax Rochester was fifteen years ago married to my sister, Bertha Antoinetta Mason at St James church, Spanish Town, Jamaica.
The record of the marriage will be found in the register of that church - a copy of it is now in my possession. Signed, Richard Mason.
She was living two months ago.
I have a witness to the fact.
You, madam, are clearly not to blame. Your uncle will be glad to hear it.
You wrote to your uncle, did you not? To inform him you were going to marry Mr Rochester? Mr Mason was staying with him when your letter came.
Mr John Eyre has been the Madeira correspondent of the Mason trading house for some years. You can imagine his distress when Mason revealed the real state of matters.

He would have come himself but I'm sad to tell you that his health is in mortal decline. He implored Mr Mason to prevent this false marriage and referred him to me for assistance. I only hope that he survives long enough to hear that you are safe.
